item.name: 2 de Mayo
item.comment: A unique two-player game with a very thoughtful historical theme. I like how both players have different goals to accomplish. It creates an interesting tension. This isn't something that you'll get out and play all the time, but it is a great change-of-pace game when it is just you and one other person.

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment: This game is quick, strategic, and fun. The deck-drafting mechanic is not original, but is perfectly executed in 7 Wonders. My family loves it, and yet gamers still like to play it. Deserved all the awards it won. Build an entire ancient civilization in 30 minutes? Sign me up!

item.name: Age of Discovery
item.comment: Really solid and underrated game, but it is definitely a "typical" Eurogame, so it goes under the radar.
item.conditiontext: Perfect condition, only played once. I thought it was a terrific game, but my group just didn't take to it, so it is taking up space. Hoping someone will take it and appreciate it as much as I do.

item.name: Age of Empires III: The Age of Discovery
item.comment: I find that this game is a Eurogame that doesn't feel like a Euro game. It is a bit more action-packed, or at least seems like it when you're playing. At a basic level, it is just a worker-placement game, but the theme is carried out so well that you feel like you're really conquering and settling the New World... well, as much as a board game can make you feel like that!

item.name: Alhambra
item.comment: A great gateway game, Alhambra is an aesthetically pleasing, calm Euro game that is easy enough to get non-gamers into, while offering enough strategy to keep real gamers interested. This is one of the games I bring out when the in-laws come by. :-D

item.name: Amerigo
item.comment: This is yet another rock-solid Eurogame from Stefan Feld, though I was surprised at how light it felt. I am ok with that, though. My one complaint is this--the game looks so, so epic and exciting. But it isn't. It is another dry Eurogame by Stefan Feld. Don't get me wrong! For what it is in reality, it is terrific! Love it so far! But there is still a part of me that wishes it was as swashbuckling as it looks. Oh well. Never judge a book by its cover.

item.name: Apples to Apples
item.comment: A classic party game that is really fun, but gets old after awhile. Still, it is almost a must-have because everyone likes it and is familiar with it, so it gets a lot of requests in mixed company.

item.name: Axis & Allies Europe 1940
item.comment: Axis & Allies is epic and well-made, but I tend to find it much too repetitive for a game that takes so long to play. But for what it is, it is very well thought out and well-balanced. If you're looking for an epic war game, this might just be the one you're looking for!

item.name: Axis & Allies Pacific 1940
item.comment: Same holds true for this as for Axis & Allies Europe--well-made and balanced, but too repetitive for such a long playing time. That said, very pleased to see the Pacific out. Europe-based WWII books and games are so much more numerous.

item.name: Battle Line
item.comment: Battle Line is a little too repetitive and simple for my tastes, but it is still a solid poker-like war game that plays quickly. A decent filler, but not my favorite.

item.name: Canterbury
item.comment: Backed this one Kickstarter and am quite happy with it. The game is not much to look at, but brings a really fresh feel to it. Very strategic and unique, which is exactly what I like in a game. The one thing I wish is that the buildings you place were more varied.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment: A classic! This is the game that got me into board games again after not really playing much for two decades. It is simple and easy to learn, yet offers a great depth of thought and strategy.

item.name: Castle Panic
item.comment: Not the most sophisticated game ever, but a real fun change-of-pace for its uniqueness. Work together to thwart the raving monsters attempting to storm your castle. Can be really challenging to win, despite its simplicity! A good cooperative game.

item.name: Castle Panic: The Wizard's Tower
item.comment: Adds some variety to an already solid game. I likely would have traded my Castle Panic away, but the Wizard's Tower really increased its replayability.

item.name: Catan
item.comment: This is the classic Eurogame that got everyone into Eurogames. I appreciate the game very much, but honestly? I find it a little dull. Maybe the expansions make it better, but I have not had a chance to play those. Still, a solid game and an influential one.

item.name: Caylus
item.comment: Having finally had a chance to play this, I see why it is so highly esteemed! It is amazing how a game can be so simple and complex at the same time. Typical theme, but very unique playing mechanics.

item.name: Chess
item.comment: A classic when you're looking for a thoughtful, abstract zen experience. I used to be an avid player, but one day I just was chessed out. Still have a healthy respect for chess and its advocates, though. It's one of the grand-parents of board games!

item.name: Clue: The Simpsons
item.comment: Us board game geeks tend to forget some of the old classics, but this is still fun to pull out once in awhile. My version is "The Simpsons" version, and it is in great shape. Box and board are "as new." All the pieces are there, and the vast majority of the notebook pages are still unused.
item.conditiontext: To be clear: this is the 2002 Simpsons version of Clue. It is in excellent shape, with only a few of the notebook pages used. All the pieces are there, and the board and box are in perfect condition.

item.name: Commands & Colors: Napoleonics
item.comment: I absolutely LOVE this game. It found that sweet spot between CC: Ancients and all its hand-to-hand combat and Memoir '44 and all its shooting from a distance. One of my favorite themes, too, but then again I am a historian of the period.

item.name: Commands & Colors: Napoleonics Expansion #1 – The Spanish Army
item.comment: Exactly what you want from an expansion like this: more armies, more terrain, and more scenarios. Thumbs up!

item.name: Commands & Colors: Napoleonics Expansion #2 – The Russian Army
item.comment: Exactly what you want from an expansion like this: more armies, more terrain, and more scenarios. Thumbs up!

item.name: Commands & Colors: Napoleonics Expansion #3 – The Austrian Army
Commands & Colors: Napoleonics Expansion #4 – The Prussian Army
Cosmic Encounter
item.comment: A classic game of alliances and backstabbing in space. I love the wide-variety of different aliens you get to choose from.

item.name: Council of Verona
item.comment: Another one of those Love Letteresque small card games that are popular, and a really solid one. I think I like it a little better than Love Letter, provided you have the poison expansion. The Romeo and Juliet theme is very well-done, and it is cheap, small, and portable.

item.name: Cyclades
item.comment: A really great thematic, light war-game based on Greek mythology. Love the little figures that come with it, and I also love how well it scales to different amounts of players, though it is at its best with 4.

item.name: Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
Dixit
item.comment: This is my favorite "party" game for the family. It is fun to play, and has a special aesthetic quality to it that no other game has. It is philosophy meets art meets fun.

item.name: Dixit Odyssey
item.comment: Adding Odyssey to the original Dixit games makes the two of them become the perfect family game.

item.name: Dixit Quest
item.comment: The original Dixit becomes better and better the more cards you have to add to it for variety. Big thumbs up to simple expansions!

item.name: Dominion
item.comment: I personally think Dominion is a little overrated. I mean, ultimately you are just drawing and playing cards over and over. But it is SO well-loved and offers so much variety of strategies due to the large mix of different cards you can choose from that even if overrated, it is still a great game with a wide range of options!

item.name: Dominion: Prosperity
item.comment: Adding cards to Dominion makes for even more variety. No two games ever have to be alike! The only catch is that you are soon wading in piles and piles of cards that become difficult to keep up with.

item.name: The Downfall of Pompeii
item.comment: Ha ha! What a simple, but fun game. This is nothing deep, but the rules are easy to teach, the strategy is challenging despite the luck aspect, and the theme is fantastic. This game is always good for a laugh and a little diabolical, but good-natured backstabbing.

item.name: Dragonology: The Game
item.comment: This game is a bit simplistic, but it is better than its rating suggests, especially when played with children.

item.name: Dungeon Command: Blood of Gruumsh
item.comment: By themselves, the Dungeon Command games are decent, but nothing special. 12 miniatures to battle with, four tiles, and a small deck of cards does not really offer much variety and you HAVE To buy another set to really play. Put the costs together, and it is questionable whether it is worth it for just 24 units. But it is a solid game despite this problems. BUT... if you own any of the D&D cooperative games, you can ALSO add the miniatures to that for more variety there! My rating is based solely on the game as a stand-alone, but I really own it as an expansion for my Wrath of Ashardalon and Castle Ravenloft games.

item.name: Dungeon Command: Sting of Lolth
item.comment: By themselves, the Dungeon Command games are decent, but nothing special. 12 miniatures to battle with, four tiles, and a small deck of cards does not really offer much variety and you HAVE To buy another set to really play. Put the costs together, and it is questionable whether it is worth it for just 24 units. But it is a solid game despite this problems. BUT... if you own any of the D&D cooperative games, you can ALSO add the miniatures to that for more variety there! My rating is based solely on the game as a stand-alone, but I really own it as an expansion for my Wrath of Ashardalon and Castle Ravenloft games.

item.name: Dungeon Command: Tyranny of Goblins
item.comment: A little bit disappointed with the variety of figures in this batch. The other Dungeon Command games provided better options.

item.name: Dungeon Lords
item.comment: One of my all-time favorites. Great theme. Great game play. Great strategy. Unique mechanics. And you never really know for sure who won until the very end.

item.name: Dungeon Lords: Festival Season
item.comment: A nice, solid addition to Dungeon Lords, which is one of my all-time favorite games. The pets are maybe a little on the cute side, but they add a great dimension to the game. The extra rooms and unique buying spots add some great variety. The new Paladins are all right. The Festival Season and bards also add some new twists. All these things are good for variety and replayability. But what I really was excited about was getting new monsters and traps! I loved the gameplay as it was, so just this made it worth buying this. Highly recommended!

item.name: Dungeon Roll
item.comment: This is a cute and fun game, albeit one full of luck. It works great as a solo game, good as a two-player, and so-so with three. But four? You pretty much need a second copy of the game to even think of playing it that way. It was worth the $15 for the Kickstarter version, but I am on the fence whether the regular version is worth $20.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
item.comment: Really enjoy this game, especially when mixed with the monsters from Wrath of Ashardalon to give it a little more variety. Sometimes I think the event cards are a little harsh considering how often they turn up, making the game mildly aggravating at times, but overall it is a fun cooperative dungeon crawl when you're in the mood for that!

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: The Legend of Drizzt Board Game
item.comment: More of the same from an already great series of games.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Wrath of Ashardalon Board Game
item.comment: Maybe it is a dumbed-down version of D&D role-playing, but it is a ton of fun to play. The figures and components are well-done and you get to fight together with your friends against monsters in a dungeon. My only complaint is that there are not more cards to customize your character, but this is effectively resolved by combining it with its sister D&D games.

item.name: Fact or Crap
item.comment: Mother-in-Law bought it for me. It's a silly trivia game that is fun to play once, but after you go through the cards once... it gets stale. Still, if you are into this kind of party game, maybe you'll like it better.

item.name: Fantastiqa
item.comment: I am rather shocked at how much fun I have playing this game despite its being rather simple (game is for 8 and above). It really is just a deck-building game, but somehow it is more than that. Well-designed, and absolutely beautifully made. One of the nicest looking games I have ever seen. If you have friends, I cannot recommend a game higher than this one. If you don't, I still recommend it.

item.name: Forbidden Desert
item.comment: I seem to be in the minority of people who actually likes Forbidden Island better. Not sure why. It just seems like more "fun." But Forbidden Desert is a good changeup, and is definitely a little bit more complex. So it is a keeper.

item.name: Forbidden Island
item.comment: A simple, fast game, but a good one. This is one of my favorites for nights when the "big" game ends a little earlier than expected and we are out of competitive juice. Fun, light cooperative game with a good "tension" to it.

item.name: Freedom: The Underground Railroad
item.comment: This game was a grand slam to me. It has a very awesome, unique, historical theme. It is educational, but still a lot of fun. And it is a challenging cooperative game, which my group can never seem to get enough of. Great components. Great gameplay. I cannot say enough about how good thing game is.

item.name: Fresco
item.comment: Unique theme with a lot of options for winning, this game is a good gateway game to Eurogames. A little more advanced than Carcassonne, but not too heavy either. I love the aesthetics of this game.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment: This game is Mucho Fun! Hits that perfect mix of humor, strategy, uniqueness, and luck. We have gotten a lot of laughs out of this game and still are not bored with it.

item.name: The Game of Life: Pirates of the Caribbean – Dead Man's Chest
item.comment: It is the Game of Life... only with Jack Sparrow and the rest of the Pirates of the Caribbean crew. Solid game if you are into the classics, only with a little flair and a must-have for Pirates fans.
item.conditiontext: Excellent condition. Only played a couple of times. All pieces present and accounted for! Box is missing the original insert, but that is only because I bagged the components for safe-keeping.

item.name: Glen More
item.comment: This very quickly became a family favorite in our house, in part because we like the theme (Scottish clans building their lands, raising sheep, and making whiskey), and part way because although very easy to learn and very laid back, it is competitive and offers a lot of strategy.

item.name: Gloom
item.comment: This is certainly not a heavy game and is more about the game experience than it is about winning or losing, provided you play it right and tell the stories of your characters as you kill them. Good way to vent! LOL!

item.name: Gloom: Unwelcome Guests
item.comment: The only expansion, IMO, that really adds anything useful to the game.

item.name: Guillotine
item.comment: Just a little fun and dumb with a theme that is in my academic field. :-)

item.name: Hanabi
item.comment: Hanabi is a bit too abstract for my tastes, but it is definitely innovative and a great change of pace. Never played anything quite like it before, and at the price, it's definitely worth taking a look at.

item.name: Le Havre
item.comment: I was never drawn to Le Havre because the shipping theme is a little dull for my tastes, but having played it now I am seeing why it is so highly regarded. The game mechanics are terrific! If this had a more exciting theme, I am sure it would catapult up toward the top of my favorite games list.

item.name: HeroQuest
item.comment: This is the game that got me into theme-based board games. No, it was not the most in-depth game ever, and my little sister hated it, but when I was a teen there was no better game in the world for me. I am still really sad that my sisters lost all the pieces after I went to college. I am shocked and dismayed that no one has reprinted it after all these years.

item.name: Infiltration
item.comment: This game has only average ratings, really, but I really enjoy it. It is a unique game in which you infiltrate the evil Android universe corporation to steal information. The game play is very original and action-packed. Lots of tension, suspense, and variety in this really unique game.

item.name: Infinite City
item.comment: There is nothing new in this game, but it is a solid one-hour game similar to Carcassonne, only a tad bit more complex and modern.

item.name: It Happens..
item.comment: Nothing special, but a solid enough dice game. Came free with a Kickstarter I backed and is good with the nieces and nephews, so I keep it around. It's cute.

item.name: Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot
item.comment: This is a really fun and goofy game, and perfect for those days when you just want to have some silly fun stabbing one another in the back. My wife is not too fond of it, unfortunately, so it does not get played very often. I agree with her on one point--it is too easy to run out of bunnies, which leaves you just sitting there for several turns until you can refresh your hand. That is, indeed, one weakness of the game.
item.conditiontext: Only played a couple of times, so everything is in excellent condition, including the box.

item.name: Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot RED Booster
item.comment: This expansion is worth owning if only to get the barrier cards.

item.name: King of Tokyo
item.comment: This game is not very deep and only has a minimal amount of strategy, but it sure is a lot of fun. Fast, simple, and just a little bit goofy; it's a great filler game and fills that "action movie" niche for when you are not in the mood for the highbrow drama of a Eurogame.

item.name: King of Tokyo: Power Up!
item.comment: The panda "monster" is a little too cute, but the Evolution cards in Power Up! are a must to for King of Tokyo to maintain is replayability. Highly recommended.

item.name: Kingdoms
item.comment: This game is decent and very simple, but with all the math involved, I think it makes a better phone app than it makes an actual board game.

item.name: Kremlin
item.comment: I have the new Jolly Roger version of this, and the rule book is a mess. But the game is still pretty darned good, and for the price you can't do much better. Great strategy and back-stabbing political game with really innovative mechanics.

item.name: The Ladies of Troyes
item.comment: I was a little bit disappointed with this... but really only because I had very high expectations. Troyes is one of my all-time favorite games. The expansion adds three more influential figures to it, which is nice, but I wish there were more. I also would have liked to see more black event cards. Other than that, this was terrific. The new places to send your workers and the large array of extra red, yellow, and white cards really bumped up the variety. Each game is even more likely than ever to have the subtle differences that make this game so replayable and fun.

item.name: Lancaster
item.comment: Lancaster is, to me, one of the essentials of Eurogames. It does the worker-placement thing very well, and adds just enough excitement to the theme to make you feel like you're doing more than cube-pushing. Good strategy. Good theme. And it has expansions that make it even better.

item.name: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
item.comment: My sister owns this and loved it. I like it quite a bit, too. It is not the most well-thought out game of all time, but it is very unique and a lot of fun. And if you like Marvel comics, it is a home run! Gets even better when you add the expansions!

item.name: Liberté
item.comment: I am a historian of the French Revolution, and so the theme for this one hits my sweet spot. A complex and sophisticated Eurogame that utilizes its theme a LOT better than most people realize, though in very subtle ways. My only complaint is that the "battles" are a little weak. Everything else is a home run.

item.name: London
item.comment: Typical Eurogame... but a really good one. Rebuilding London never was so much fun! Great combination of card play and token placement.

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep
item.comment: Lords of Waterdeep is a Euro-styled worker-placement game that, although on the light side, offers a plethora of choices and depth. The theme makes it feel a little more "fun" than other Eurogames, and it is the perfect game when you want to just relax and have some fun without resorting to more arbitrary, goofy games like King of Tokyo.

item.name: Love Letter
item.comment: To hear the hype, you'd think this was the next best thing since Settlers of Catan first came out. It really isn't THAT awesome of a game in the overall scheme of things. However, it is, indeed, a really good filler for a really good price and it doesn't take up hardly any room. So it's a keeper.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game
item.comment: I wish this had more and more diverse characters to choose from--only four characters!!??--but otherwise this is a big hit. I am one of the few and proud who loves Talisman despite its "randomness," but I admit it--this takes Talisman-like games to the next level.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game: Krang Character Expansion
Mage Knight Board Game: The Lost Legion
Magic: The Gathering
item.comment: I hate collectible card games. If you don't engulf yourself in this and pay zillions of dollars, you'll never be competitive with serious players. And yet, although the cards in this game have amazing art, the game itself is actually a little boring after awhile. Ultimately I think this is a good game, but it is too expensive for what it is.

item.name: Marrying Mr. Darcy
item.comment: I bought Marrying Mr. Darcy for my wife--a Jane Austen fanatic--and it was definitely a hit with her! The game is a little bit too random and light for a gamer, but it was still fun and good for a laugh, especially if you are even remotely familiar with Pride and Prejudice. There's the rub--if you don't really follow the Jane Austen crowd, the game probably doesn't have much to offer.

item.name: Masterpiece
item.comment: This is an oldie that I picked up for old-times' sake. Used to play it as a kid, though in today's gaming world it does not add much.

item.name: Medici
item.comment: Medici is a rock-solid auction game. It probably could provide a little more variety in its game-play, but it is interactive and easy to play, and I really enjoy the theme.

item.name: Mice and Mystics
item.comment: So far we have found this game surprisingly challenging, despite having a children's story feel to it. If you like cooperative games with great aesthetics, terrific components, and a little silliness mixed in with adventure, this is the perfect game. My only complaints are that it can be a little clunky at times and some of the scenarios do not scale well to different numbers of players.

item.name: Mission: Red Planet
item.comment: I love the theme for this--it is a steam punk Victorian space race game. To Mars! The game mechancs make it a fairly standard worker-placement/area control game, and some of the components are a little flimsy, but it looks great and is a lot of fun! Shame it is out of print (as of March 2013, anyway).

item.name: Modern Art
item.comment: A good, solid auction game for when you want a little more player interaction, but not too much thinking and complexity.

item.name: Monopoly
item.comment: Though I only give this game a 6, mostly because I played it to death back in the day, Monopoly is very underrated in the gaming community today due to two things. One, everyone else played it to death back in the day, too, and they are sick of it. Two, most people played it to death WRONG. Actually read the rules and this game is much more interactive and exciting than people think.

item.name: Monopoly: My NHL
item.comment: This game is well-designed for a Monopoly variant. It is basically just Monopoly, only with NHL teams, but what is really amazing about it is the production value. The metal token pieces are fantastic, and the stickers not only make the game fully customizable (you can make "Boardwalk" any team you like), but they are fully removable. I have had the game now for six years and they still come off and go back on like I just bought them.
item.conditiontext: This game is in terrific condition. It was only played once, which means the stickers have been used, but they are still perfectly removable and restickable, as designed. Everything else is as it was when it was bought. The pewter pieces are especially cool.

item.name: Monty Python Fluxx
item.comment: Just something fun, light, and goofy for days when you're playing with the wife and family.

item.name: Mr. Jack
item.comment: I got this for my sister and wish I had my own copy! It is nothing complicating, but the cat-and-mouse chase is well-thought out and plays really quickly. It was fun when we, at first, thought it was virtually impossible to win as Jack. Now we're not too sure how to win as the cops! A terrific filler game for two people.

item.name: Munchkin
item.comment: Included with this are the first four expansions: Munchkin 2: Unnatural Axe Munchkin 3: Clerical Errors Munchkin 4: The Need for Steed Munchkin 5: De-Ranged

item.name: Mystery of the Abbey
item.comment: This may be the best deduction game I have ever played. Definitely a hit with the family! It is not quite so random as Clue and has a little more action to it than Martin Wallace's P.I. My mom even likes it, and she is not all that good at deduction games usually.

item.name: Neuroshima Hex!
item.comment: This is a really good game with a really good theme, but there is something about the simple tile-laying that seems just a tiny bit stale. I guess it has just been done before. It needs a little something to spice if up. Overall, however, an enjoyable enough game with a lot of potential.

item.name: The New Science
item.comment: Awfully fun for something so educational New Science is a great action-selection game that recreates the Scientific Revolution in an innovative and entertaining way. Be Galileo or Newton and invent modern science! Fun! My only complaint is that it does not scale down to fewer players as well as it should--you lose half the board almost.

item.name: Nightfall
item.comment: Wasn't so sure I was going to like Nightfall--I am not that big into card fighting games. But I had a chance to play this a few times now and found that it is really quite enjoyable. The vampire-werewolf theme is old, but very well done. The game play and mechanics are very well thought out. That you can do this with more than just two people is a big plus, too. For the price, I don't know that you can do better in this genre.

item.name: Nightfall: Martial Law
item.comment: Slightly disappointed with this game as a stand-alone game. It just doesn't flow as well as the original Nightfall. But as an expansion to integrate with the original? Fantastic. Adds a lot of variety to the game.

item.name: Ninjato
item.comment: I was looking for a good game with a "ninja" theme. I am a big "theme" person. This one appealed to me because it captures the big picture of what being a ninja was all about. It wasn't just hacking and slashing in the shadows! The one thing it needs to be perfect? Assassinations!

item.name: No Thanks!
item.comment: Great filler game that is cheap, fast, fun, and really easy to teach. It is my usual sort of game, but the perfect game to get out for the in-laws.

item.name: On the Underground
item.comment: I was yammering on once about how Ticket to Ride should do a city underground version, but then I found out about this game and got it as a gift. The similarities are startling between the two games, but there are just enough differences to make it worth having both. And now I won't forget the locations of the stops when I'm in London!

item.name: P.I.
item.comment: P.I. is a really solid deduction game with an absolutely fantastic theme. I want to love it, but it is missing a little something. I cannot put my finger on what. Still, whatever it is, it is the difference between a good game and a great game, not a good game and a bad game. So I still recommend this if you like deduction with a film noir theme.

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: The board game snob in me doesn't want to like Pandemic because regular stores are starting to sell it. LOL! But Pandemic is so well-known for a reason--it is intense fun for the whole family. One of the best cooperative games on the market with a really unique theme!

item.name: Pandemic: In the Lab
item.comment: This expansion made the game for me. By itself, Pandemic is fun, but a little too simplistic for repeated play. In the Lab gives the game some theme and depth that really raises it the bar, perhaps making it the best cooperative game I have ever played.

item.name: Pandemic: On the Brink
item.comment: I was happy to get some extra roles to play, but for the most part I was not that impressed by this expansion. It adds a lot of variants, but most of the variants really are not that much fun. I preferred the In the Lab expansion.

item.name: Pirate Fluxx
item.comment: Like all Fluxx games, this is just a little fun and dumb for a night with the family. This is my favorite theme of all the Fluxx games.

item.name: Pirate's Cove
item.comment: This game is nearly the perfect pirate game. Could use a bigger variety of pirates to run into besides you and your opponents, and movement is not particularly exciting. But I love the components, the ship-to-ship fighting, the strategy, and the theme! ARRR!

item.name: Pirateology: The Game
item.comment: I am surprised at how low this game is rated. Granted, it is more geared toward kids, but I find this is an excellent game to play with the young ones because it is simple enough to teach, but complex enough to be interesting. The components are top-notch! The rules could be better written, though, and I admit you have to house-rule a few vague parts of the rulebook. Otherwise, a solid game that is good for families!
item.conditiontext: All the pieces, which were quite impressive, are there and it is in excellent shape. Only played a couple of times. We have the "Dragonology" game, too, and that is really the only reason I am parting with this underestimated game.

item.name: Pokémon Trading Card Game
item.comment: I don't really like CCGs, but I bought a bunch of these way back when my sisters were little and loved it so that I could play with them. When they outgrew it, I outgrew it. Still, it was good for what it was. One of these days I'll break it out again with the nieces and nephews.

item.name: Power Grid: Factory Manager
item.comment: My gaming group is not that keen on this game, but I really enjoyed it. It has a unique theme, and a lot of interesting decisions to make.

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: This classic Euro-game has a great reputation for a great reason. It is just about the perfect design for a worker placement game and it has a relatively unique theme--though it has since been copied by other games.

item.name: Ra
item.comment: I like the interaction of auction games, though they do tend to get a little repetitive. Ra is a rock solid one, though, and provides a really neat and unique theme. I like that there are multiple strategies for winning as well, and that you never know for sure when the auction will occur!

item.name: Railways of Europe
item.comment: Just a new map for the Railways of Europe game! Can always use a new map to add some variety. Nice!

item.name: Railways of the World
item.comment: I thought and pondered and fretted for months over which train game to get and finally decided on Railways of the World. I cannot speak for Steam, Age of Steam, and all the others, but this game was a huge home run for me. Great strategy, great components, and an aesthetic beauty that appeals to my board game soul. My only complaint is that the designers or publishers could not figure out what the difference was between pink and purple. They are NOT the same color!!

item.name: Rattus
item.comment:
Gameplay for Rattus is fairly average, but it has several things going for it that keeps it in my collection: 1. Really unique, historical theme. 2. Not very expensive. 3. Not very big.
I hear the Pied Piper expansion really improves it, but it is difficult to obtain here in the States. :-(

item.name: Risk
item.comment: A classic, albeit a long one! Mine is the 1993 edition and it has ALL the pieces still, including the "mission" cards. But I have to admit that the board and box are a little beat up. The board is warped and split, but it is still playable. The box is all in one piece, but it is definitely dinged up. Best used for the pieces, which are in perfect shape.
item.conditiontext: Full disclosure: this game is beat up. All the pieces are present and accounted for, and are in pristine shape. All the "mission" cards are present as well and are fine. But the board is quite warped and split in one of the folds, though it is still playable. The box is definitely dinged up--it looks its 20 year age--but it is in one piece. But if this is what you are looking for, here it is!

item.name: The Road to Canterbury
item.comment: Love this game. It is beautiful to look at, has really unique mechanics, really unique theme, and it perfect for three players, so I can play it with my mom and sister.

item.name: Road to Enlightenment
item.comment: Road to Enlightenment is allllmost a great game. I absolutely love the game's theme and the basic gameplay is excellent and innovative, but there are so many little nit-picky problems with it. The designer is supposed to be fixing those with an expansion, though, and I can hardly wait. I like this game. I want to love it, and I think that it is almost there.

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
item.comment: One of the most unique, challenging, and thematic cooperative games I have ever played. Really great if you have an interactive group. I imagine it would suck playing with an alpha-gamer, but our group does not have one. Big thumbs up!

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
item.comment: This is one of my favorite filler games. If it was a little bit more than just rolling dice, I might rate it even higher, but as is it is a fun and quick game that accomplishes quite a complex theme in a very simple, quick game!

item.name: Samurai
item.comment: I played this before Neuroshima Hex, and that may be why I found Neuroshima a little stale. Strategic placing of army tiles has been done. That said, both Neuroshima and Samurai are solid, fun games that combine simplicity with thoughtful strategy, without taking up hours of your time.

item.name: San Juan
item.comment: Good, solid card game version of Puerto Rico, but I find that when I am playing it I just want to go play Puerto Rico. San Juan just lacks that "je ne sais pas" quality. Still, for its portability and price, it is worth checking out.

item.name: Scrabble
item.comment: Another classic, but I admit this is more fun on the smart phone than it is in real life. LOL!

item.name: Seasons
item.comment: I need a few more plays to really make up my mind on this, but after one go at it, I was really surprised how much fun this was. The way the custom dice work is really original and unique, and the game has a terrific flow. Casting spells was never such a blast!

item.name: Seasons: Enchanted Kingdom
item.comment: This expansion is a little disappointing. Didn't really add much, and some of what it adds it just kind of boring. I would have been happier just with more cards to use!

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment: This is one of the most unique games I have ever played. Great game for cooperation, theme, planning, and betrayal! With the right group, it never gets old.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot: Merlin's Company
item.comment: Slightly disappointed with this one. The new characters were nice and Merlin definitely adds to the game, but the travel cards needed more to them and what I really want are more quests to embark on!

item.name: Shogun
item.comment: Love this game. The cube tower is innovative, the game has a good mix of battling and administration, and it has a great theme!

item.name: Small World
item.comment: This is a favorite of mine. Great theme and I love the way the skills and races interact. Perfect for when you want a lighter strategy game that plays in an hour.

item.name: Small World Realms
item.comment: I was really happy with this expansion. I love Small World, but it lacked something to make it more replayable, especially with only two or three people usually playing. The ability to change up the map was exactly what I was looking for! Nice.

item.name: Small World: Grand Dames of Small World
item.comment: A little disappointing, but a few new races never hurt.

item.name: Smart Ass
item.comment: This is my mom-in-law's game and it is pretty fun, but a little too easy, especially if you are skilled at trivia games, and the randomness of moving can be irksome. Could use more spaces to stretch the playing time a bit.

item.name: Space Alert
item.comment: Played this the other night for the first time and I can't stop thinking about how much fun I had! It is complex and chaotic, for sure, but what a blast!

item.name: Space Alert: The New Frontier
item.comment: One of the best expansions I've ever bought. Gives you a lot more enemies, variants, and goodies without mucking with the original gameplay too much. Perfect!

item.name: Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game
item.comment: The 12-year-old in me LOVES this game. The 40-year-old in me gets annoyed setting it up and putting it away. LOL!

item.name: Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game – A-Wing Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game – B-Wing Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game – Imperial Aces Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game – Millennium Falcon Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game – Slave I Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game – TIE Advanced Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game – TIE Bomber Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game – TIE Fighter Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game – TIE Interceptor Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game – X-Wing Expansion Pack
Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game – Y-Wing Expansion Pack
Stone Age
item.comment: Stone Age is a really good, solid Euro-style game with a really unique theme of Stone Age civilization. Well-designed, great components, and multiple ways to victory--it is a quintessential Eurogame, which might be its only problem. Aside of the unique theme, it just feels like every other Eurogame you've ever played. I like it! I like it a lot! But there are other similar-styled games that I like better.

item.name: Struggle of Empires
item.comment: For a game with such simple rules, I was really surprised at the depth of strategy involved with this historically-themed game of alliances, exploration, and conquering. A great game to introduce newbies to more in-depth Eurogames/war games. I especially love how the theme integrates. If you are familiar with the real history of the eighteenth-century, you'll get a great amount of entertainment playing "what if" with reality.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Master Set
item.comment: I like the idea of this game better than the game itself. It has a really solid fantasy theme and a lot of cool expansions to give it some variety. The cards are pretty awesome and there is, indeed, a lot of strategy. However, I find I get bored of two-player games where I am just laying cards down on a board over and over. So I think this game is good, but not great.

item.name: Taboo
item.comment: Just a solid party game that is easy to play and appropriate for virtually any group who can read. It is not my favorite game, but it is a family classic for the right moment.

item.name: Tales of the Arabian Nights
item.comment: This game is a load of laughs. The wacky situations you find yourself in more than makes up for the randomness involved. Not a game you'll play twenty times in a row, but when it does make the table it is always an exciting story.

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition): The Dungeon Expansion
item.comment: This expansion adds some much-needed variety to the base game, which involves too much going around in circles. The only thing is that the difficulty of it makes it so that by the time you get to end of it, you may as well have gone toward the Crown of Power to win! A little house-ruling on the strength of the "boss" helps and ultimately makes this a good addition.

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition): The Frostmarch Expansion
item.comment: The smaller expansions to Talisman really enrich the game a lot. I understand some people's dislike of the base game, but adding more spells, monsters, characters, and endings makes Talisman an epic game of unpredictable delight.

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition): The Highland Expansion
item.comment: This expansion, like the Dungeons expansion, adds variety to a game which in its original conception really needed it. A lot of fun, but there is one knock on it--the rewards you get for completing it are kind of disappointing!

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition): The Reaper Expansion
item.comment: The smaller expansions to Talisman really enrich the game a lot. I understand some people's dislike of the base game, but adding more spells, monsters, characters, and endings makes Talisman an epic game of unpredictable delight. This one adds a rather random "Grim Reaper," which at first we hated. Now we cannot bear to be without him, because he really makes the middle portion of the game a little more interesting!

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition): The Sacred Pool Expansion
item.comment: More spells, monsters, characters, and endings! Awesome. I especially like the "cooperative" variant this provides.

item.name: Talisman (Revised 4th Edition)
item.comment: This game gets a bad rap by a lot of people here, and I understand why. It's a long game with a lot of random events. But I love the multitude of characters and all the surprises! And the expansions make it so unpredictable that no game is ever the same. It's an epic adventure if you have the right personality for it, but you really do need the expansions to make it so you are not just wandering around in circles for two hours.

item.name: Thurn and Taxis
item.comment: Thurn and Taxis is a simple, basic worker-placement, route-creating game about building a postal empire in old Bavaria. It offers little new to the genre, but still remains a really solid game. What I really like about it is that it is simple and easy to play, while still providing enough subtle strategy options to keep it interesting. What you have here is an A+ gateway game to Eurogames for beginners that won't bore the expert to death. Nice.

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment: This game is so simple, and although I do not find it as fun as TtR Europe or Nordic Countries, it is a really solid game. I will always be surprised how much fun I had playing it. Highly recommend it for something that both kids and adults can play together. They'll even learn some geography!

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 1 – Team Asia & Legendary Asia
item.comment: These maps are excellent and add some variety to the base Ticket to Ride, but I do wish the China map had been a little better spelled out for games without teams.

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 2 – India & Switzerland
item.comment: If there was anything that I didn't like about Ticket to Ride, which is one of my favorite games, it was playing on the same map over and over again. These map collections really blew the cover off this game for me. I never get bored of it, and I usually prefer more complex and advanced games!

item.name: Ticket to Ride Map Collection: Volume 3 – The Heart of Africa
item.comment: I am really, really, really disappointed that we only get one side of the board for this expansion. Northern Africa would have been a fantastic addition to this on the other side. The terrain cards are an interesting addition, but you definitely could live without them. Overall I am just excited to have an extra map to play on for variety's sake. A good expansion, but not a great one.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Alvin & Dexter
item.comment: This was cute, but we very rarely bring it out. Just makes an otherwise enjoyable game a little aggravating.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Europa 1912
item.comment: More destination cards! Yes! Simple expansion, but a great addition to the core game.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Europe
item.comment: This is, IMO, the best of the Ticket to Ride games. It provides more complexity than the original U.S.A. map version, and has a better balance to it than some of the later versions. Definitely one of the family favorites!

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Nordic Countries
item.comment: Sometimes just my wife and I are around to play, and this version made for a more challenging map for the two-player days. Learned some great new geography, too!

item.name: Tigris & Euphrates
item.comment: I was a little disappointed with this one theme-wise. The theme is definitely just tacked on. But it is a solid area-control token game with some interesting mechanics and a ton of strategy and replayability. Good, solid game.

item.name: Tikal
item.comment: This game has a really neat theme--you are archeologists searching for temples and treasure in the Mayan jungles of Mexico. The mechanics do not seem very new today, but they are well done and were quite original when it came out. The game seems a little stale now, but it was a fresh game in its day and is still fun to play.

item.name: A Touch of Evil: Hero Pack 1
item.comment: Not a lot here, but the addition of new bad guys, characters, and more cards definitely improved an already well-done game.

item.name: A Touch of Evil: Hero Pack 2
A Touch of Evil: Something Wicked Expansion
item.comment: Something Wicked made an already great cooperative game almost perfect. The only thing we didn't like about the original was the lack of locations to wander around. Problem solved, plus more bad guys and characters! Oh my!

item.name: A Touch of Evil: The Coast
item.comment: The Coast makes Touch of Evil a complete game. I always loved the game, but the original version is lacking. Add this and "Something Wicked," however, and you have an epic adventure with a multitude of different characters where you never know quite what is going to happen. A splendid expansion.

item.name: A Touch of Evil: The Supernatural Game
item.comment: This coop game has a unique historical setting around the turn of the 18th-19th centuries, which sets it up for a variety of classic evil bad guys for you to work together to fight! Great characters. Great cards. Great game mechanics. Great mood. And almost anyone can play it. Could be the highlight of a small Halloween party! All that said, it really needs at least some of the expansions to reach its full potential. The variety of the expansions makes this a family favorite.

item.name: Triassic Terror
item.comment: DINOSAURS!! This is not the best game I have ever played by any stretch of the imagination, but it is a solid and well-designed game and it has dinosaurs. The components are especially unbelievable, though I wish they had gotten an expert opinion on a couple of the dinos they chose to include. The little pink guy, particularly, does not look like any dinosaur I ever heard of, and I am somewhat an expert. LOL! Nonetheless, a fun, family strategy game.

item.name: Troyes
item.comment: This beautiful, aesthetically pleasing game places you in medieval France where you are a member of the nobility trying to influence the city of Troyes through religion, politics, and economy while helping fight off foreign invaders and stop destructive rebellions. The unique way that the dice are used is a great mechanic. Great mix of strategy and thought, with JUST enough luck to keep it interesting.

item.name: Tsuro
item.comment: A very simple game, but an aesthetically pleasing one. A really good "zen" game, and a lot of fun if you prefer more abstract games.
item.conditiontext: This game is in perfect shape. Only played a couple of times.

item.name: Village
item.comment: This may well be my favorite Eurogame. I love the blend and variety of planning ahead, worker placement, and resource management. The game also has a really philosophical theme with great aesthetics. And you never know who is going to win until the very end! Brilliant.

item.name: Virgin Queen
item.comment: This game is epic!! Fantastic historical theme. A lot of depth. A lot of strategy. A lot of planning involved. A lot of options. A ton of fun! And it is very educational on top of all that. I loved it. The only catch is that it is so complex and so long. I finally ended up trading it because it just never made it to the table.
item.conditiontext: This game is in great shape, "like new," except for the fact that the pieces have already been punched and bagged. Bought the game, but simply cannot get my gaming group to give it a fair shake. We only played it once, and never finished. Shame. I think it is a wonderful game, but no sense in it sitting around gathering dust.

item.name: Warhammer: Invasion
item.comment: Got this for Christmas and have not had a chance to play it enough to form a strong opinion of it, but so far it seems like a really solid game that should improve with the addition of some of the expansions. Edit: I have since bought the Assault on Ulthuan expansion, and it really completes this game. Edit: After a few tries, we decided it wasn't for us and traded it. It is a good game! But I have too many other games I like better.

item.name: Warhammer: Invasion – Assault on Ulthuan
item.comment: This is the one "must-have" expansion for Warhammer: Invasions. If you are really into collectible card games, then the others are worth tackling, but if you just want one complete game, then get the original and this and you're all set.

item.name: Xia: Legends of a Drift System
Yggdrasil
item.comment: I own Castle Panic and really enjoy that game, but am tempted to trade it because Yggdrasil is everything Castle Panic is, but more. Great theme, dynamic mechanics, beautiful components, and a load of fun. One of the best cooperative games I have played.

item.name: Zombies!!!
item.comment: This game is a little silly and repetitive (I don't have the expansions at the moment, which might fix the latter). But it is a lot of fun and laughs! Great game for a little light-hearted backstabbing and adventure, and you get your own little figure that looks like Chuck Norris. Win!

item.name: Zooloretto
item.comment: I probably won't buy this for myself, but it is actually surprisingly fun. Definitely at the top of my list of potential presents for the young nieces and nephews this Christmas.
